top_paths.title: Unguarded data-to-external path (2 paths)
top_paths.path:
Gmail inbox → GmailGetThread → GmailToolkit → Gmail outbound
    Gmail inbox → GmailGetThread → TavilySearchResults → Tavily API
top_paths.description: Someone sends your agent a crafted email. The agent reads your Gmail inbox and forwards sensitive content via Gmail outbound — to an attacker-controlled address embedded in the injected instructions.
top_paths.scenario: Someone sends your agent a crafted email. The agent reads your Gmail inbox and forwards sensitive content via Gmail outbound — to an attacker-controlled address embedded in the injected instructions.
top_paths.remediation:
Fix (CrewAI):
  task = Task(
      description="...",
+     human_input=True   # review before external calls
  )

citation.stat: Tool poisoning attacks succeed 37% avg across 20 LLM agents. Best models refuse <3% of the time.

top_paths.title: Shared tool blast radius: SerperDevTool -> 9 agents
top_paths.path:
SerperDevTool (shared tool)
  |--> Activity Planner
  |--> Candidate Outreach Strategist
  |--> Chief Marketing Strategist
  |--> Email Filter Agent
  |--> Itinerary Compiler
  |--> Job Candidate Researcher
  |--> Lead Market Analyst
  |--> Matcher
  L--> Restaurant Scout
top_paths.description: SerperDevTool feeds 9 agents in crew 'MarketingPostsCrew' -- blast radius: 1 external services. If SerperDevTool returns poisoned data (prompt injection in scraped content), 9 agents are compromised simultaneously. Each has independent downstream actions, so a single point of compromise fans out to 1 external services.
evidence: Shared by: Activity Planner, Candidate Outreach Strategist, Chief Marketing Strategist, Email Filter Agent, Itinerary Compiler, Job Candidate Researcher
Shared by: Email Action Agent, Email Response Writer, Lead Market Analyst
Shared by: Financial Agent, Financial Analyst Agent, Investment Advisor Agent
top_paths.scenario: A single poisoned input to SerperDevTool would compromise your entire analysis pipeline: Activity Planner, Candidate Outreach Strategist, Chief Marketing Strategist, Email Filter Agent, Itinerary Compiler, Job Candidate Researcher.
top_paths.business_context: This finding can only exist because the graph traced the fan-out from one shared tool. No checklist produces it -- this is emergent risk from the agent architecture.

top_paths.title: Destructive action, no human gate
top_paths.path: user input -> agent reasoning -> [FileManagementToolkit] (FileManagementToolkit (framework tool), line 0) -> data loss, no undo
top_paths.description: A misinterpreted instruction could trigger [FileManagementToolkit] on production data -- with no approval step and no undo.
top_paths.scenario: The agent interprets 'clean up old records' as a reason to call [FileManagementToolkit], deleting production data with no confirmation step.

citation.stat: OWASP ranks "Human-Agent Trust Exploitation" as a top-10 agentic risk for 2026.

top_paths.title: Agent sends external messages without human review
top_paths.description: Your agent sends messages to real humans via langchain_community.agent_toolkits with no review step. A hallucinated response, wrong information, or inappropriate tone goes directly to recipients.
top_paths.scenario: The agent drafts an email response to a customer complaint. It hallucinates a refund promise that doesn't match company policy. The email is sent immediately via GmailToolkit — no one reviewed it.
top_paths.business_context: Reputation damage, incorrect commitments, potential liability.
top_paths.remediation:
Fix (CrewAI):
  task = Task(
      description="...",
+     human_input=True   # review before execution
  )

top_paths.title: Shared tool 'SerperDevTool' bridges untrusted input to external action
top_paths.path: untrusted input → Matcher → [SerperDevTool] → Lead Market Analyst → external action
top_paths.description: Agent 'Matcher' processes external/untrusted input and shares 'SerperDevTool' with agent 'Lead Market Analyst', which performs external actions. A prompt injection in the input can propagate through the shared tool context to trigger unauthorized actions.
top_paths.scenario: A crafted email arrives. 'matcher' processes it and its context is now influenced by the injected instructions. 'lead_market_analyst' shares the same tool (SerperDevTool) and acts on the contaminated context — sending a response the attacker designed.
top_paths.business_context: This is the architectural pattern behind real-world AI exfiltration incidents. No individual agent is misconfigured — the risk emerges from the interaction.
top_paths.remediation:
Isolate trust contexts between agents:
  1. Use separate tool instances for matcher and lead_market_analyst
  2. Add an output filter on matcher before passing to lead_market_analyst
  3. Add human_input=True on lead_market_analyst's outbound tasks

top_paths.title: 'Matcher' bypasses 'CV Reader' -- reads Crewai Tools directly
top_paths.path:
Crewai Tools --> CV Reader (intended filter)
Crewai Tools --> Matcher (direct access, bypassing filter)
top_paths.description: CV Reader is supposed to filter input from Crewai Tools, but Matcher reads Crewai Tools directly via the same tool. The filter agent doesn't sit on the data path -- it runs in parallel, not as a gate.
top_paths.scenario: Malicious content in Crewai Tools reaches Matcher unfiltered regardless of what CV Reader does. The filter is architecturally irrelevant.
top_paths.business_context: The control exists but data flows around it. This is worse than no control -- it creates a false sense of security.
top_paths.remediation:
Route all Crewai Tools access through CV Reader:
  1. Remove direct Crewai Tools access from Matcher
  2. Pass filtered output from CV Reader to Matcher
  3. Or add output_filter on Matcher's direct read

top_paths.title: No error handling on 27 external calls
top_paths.path: 27 external calls without try/except -> silent failures or unhandled crashes
top_paths.description: 27 external calls (database, HTTP, financial) have no error handling. A network timeout or service outage causes the agent to crash instead of degrading gracefully.
top_paths.scenario: The database goes down. The agent crashes mid-workflow instead of reporting the error, leaving the user with no feedback.
top_paths.remediation:
Fix (CrewAI):
  Wrap crew execution in error handling:

  try:
      result = crew.kickoff()
  except Exception as e:
      logger.error(f"Crew failed: {e}")
      # degrade gracefully

citation.stat: In simulation, a single agent failure poisoned 87% of downstream decisions within 4 hours.
citation.source: Galileo AI multi-agent failure research, Dec 2025

top_paths.title: No timeout on 2 HTTP calls
top_paths.path: 2 HTTP calls without timeout= -> agent hangs indefinitely
top_paths.description: 2 HTTP calls have no timeout. If any external API hangs, your agent freezes forever. In production, this becomes an outage.
top_paths.scenario: An external API goes down. The agent hangs on the HTTP call forever, consuming resources and never responding to the user.

citation.stat: 32% of developers cite reliability as the #1 barrier to production agents -- not security, not cost.
citation.source: LangChain State of Agent Engineering, 2025 -- 1,300 respondents

top_paths.title: No checkpointing detected
top_paths.path: none checkpointing + 30 capabilities -> state loss risk
top_paths.description: No checkpoint mechanism detected with 30 confirmed capabilities. Multi-step agent workflows have no persistence.
top_paths.scenario: The process crashes mid-workflow. The agent may have read data but not yet sent the response — or sent a partial response. There's no way to resume or know what was already done.
top_paths.remediation:
Fix (CrewAI):
  Enable memory on your crew:

  crew = Crew(
      agents=[...],
      tasks=[...],
+     memory=True,
+     verbose=True
  )

top_paths.title: 3-agent chain with no intermediate validation
top_paths.path: senior_engineer_agent → qa_engineer_agent → chief_qa_engineer_agent (no validation between steps)
top_paths.description: Crew 'GameBuilderCrew' runs 3 agents sequentially with no structured output validation between steps. A hallucination in step 1 propagates through the chain, gaining false confidence at each step.
top_paths.scenario: 'senior_engineer_agent' hallucinates a data point. 'qa_engineer_agent' treats it as fact and builds analysis on it. By the time 'chief_qa_engineer_agent' produces the final output, the hallucination is deeply embedded and presented with high confidence.
top_paths.business_context: Compounding hallucination risk. Each unvalidated step amplifies errors. The final output may be confidently wrong.
top_paths.remediation:
Add structured output validation between steps:
  task = Task(
      description="...",
+     output_pydantic=IntermediateResult,  # schema validates between steps
  )

signals.title: Memory writes have no provenance tracking
signals.path: Writes to 'langchain.memory' include no attribution metadata
signals.description: Writes to 'langchain.memory' include no attribution metadata (source, timestamp, agent_id). When the agent learns something wrong, you cannot determine which input caused it or when it entered the store.
signals.remediation: Add metadata to writes: collection.add(documents=[doc], metadatas=[{'source': 'tool_result', 'agent_id': AGENT_ID, 'timestamp': datetime.utcnow().isoformat()}])

signals.title: No observability or tracing detected
signals.path: No telemetry SDK or tracing configuration found
signals.description: No telemetry SDK or tracing configuration found. Agent behavior cannot be audited, monitored for drift, or debugged in production.
evidence: (no telemetry imports or env vars found)
signals.remediation: Add observability. Options: Langfuse (open source): pip install langfuse, LangSmith: set LANGCHAIN_TRACING_V2=true, OpenTelemetry: vendor-neutral, self-hostable.

signals.title: No audit trail for 19 consequential actions
signals.path: 19 confirmed actions → no logging → no forensic trail
signals.description: Your agent performs 19 confirmed consequential actions (deletions, external sends, financial ops) but has no observability library or tracing configured. When something goes wrong, there's no trail to reconstruct what happened.
evidence: (no observability imports or env vars found)
signals.scenario: A customer reports they received a wrong email from your agent. You have no logs of what the agent sent, what prompt generated it, or what data it accessed. You can't even confirm whether the email was sent.
signals.business_context: Compliance risk, inability to investigate incidents, no accountability.
signals.remediation:
Add observability. Options:
  Langfuse (open source): pip install langfuse
  LangSmith: set LANGCHAIN_TRACING_V2=true
  OpenTelemetry: vendor-neutral, self-hostable.

signals.title: Decision agent 'Review and Editing Specialist' has no structured output
signals.path: input → review_agent (decision-making) → unstructured output → downstream action
signals.description: Agent 'Review and Editing Specialist' appears to make classification or evaluation decisions but produces unstructured output. Downstream consumers have no schema to validate against, making results inconsistent and unexplainable.
signals.scenario: The agent evaluates a candidate and outputs free text. Sometimes it says 'approved', sometimes 'looks good', sometimes 'pass'. The downstream system can't reliably parse the decision.
signals.business_context: Inconsistent decisions, unexplainable outcomes, audit failure.
signals.remediation:
Fix (CrewAI):
  task = Task(
      description="...",
+     output_pydantic=ResultSchema  # enforces structured output
  )

signals.title: No cost controls on agent execution
signals.path: 30 capabilities × no iteration limit → unbounded spend
signals.description: No max_iterations, max_rpm, rate_limit, or token budget detected across 30 capabilities. A reasoning loop or retry storm can generate thousands of API calls.
signals.scenario: The agent enters a retry loop trying to parse a malformed response. Each retry makes an LLM call. After 2,000 iterations, you have a $500 API bill and no useful output.
signals.remediation:
Fix (CrewAI):
  crew = Crew(
      agents=[...],
+     max_rpm=10,        # rate limit
+     verbose=True,      # monitor execution
  )
  agent = Agent(
+     max_iter=5,        # cap reasoning loops
  )

incident_matches.name: Microsoft Copilot EchoLeak
incident_matches.attack_summary: Zero-click prompt injection via email. Copilot ingested crafted email, extracted data from OneDrive/SharePoint/Teams, and exfiltrated it through trusted Microsoft domains.
incident_matches.match_reason: Your code reads data via FileReadTool and sends it externally via SerperDevTool — the same data→external pattern that enabled Microsoft Copilot EchoLeak. In that incident, zero-click prompt injection via email.

incident_matches.name: Slack AI Data Exfiltration
incident_matches.impact: Private channel data leaked via crafted message links
incident_matches.attack_summary: Hidden instructions in Slack messages caused AI assistant to insert malicious link. Clicking it sent private channel data to attacker's server.
incident_matches.match_reason: Your code reads data via FileReadTool and sends it externally via SerperDevTool — the same data→external pattern that enabled Slack AI Data Exfiltration. In that incident, hidden instructions in slack messages caused ai assistant to insert malicious link.

incident_matches.name: Docker Ask Gordon Prompt Injection
incident_matches.impact: Sensitive data exfiltration via poisoned Docker Hub metadata
incident_matches.attack_summary: Prompt injection via crafted Docker Hub repository metadata. AI assistant auto-executed tools to fetch payloads from attacker-controlled servers without user consent.
incident_matches.match_reason: Your agent auto-executes get_10k_url_content to fetch external content — the same pattern as Docker Ask Gordon Prompt Injection. In that incident, poisoned metadata triggered tools to fetch attacker-controlled payloads.

incident_matches.name: ServiceNow Now Assist Privilege Escalation
incident_matches.attack_summary: Second-order prompt injection: low-privilege agent tricks high-privilege agent into exporting case files to external URL.
incident_matches.match_reason: Your agent architecture has cross-agent delegation where one agent can influence lead_market_analyst's actions — similar to the ServiceNow Now Assist Privilege Escalation pattern where a low-privilege agent tricked a high-privilege agent into exfiltrating data.
